pros: My department is full of wonderful colleagues and in my role, I'm able to engage with folks in many areas of the University. The work is rewarding and I feel challenged everyday. I've grown quickly in my role with regular exposure to new aspects of the University.

pros: Benefits, work/home life balance, vacation/sick time, etc.

review_title: Positive work-study experience, fantastic and dedicated staff - Worked on Library Staff
pros: Worked in the library, and would rate the overall experience as very positive. I had a tremendous amount of free reign, and the staff is incredibly understanding, nice, and helpful. They are appreciative of every task you complete, no matter how small, and give you a large amount of freedom in organizing and accomplishing the jobs they give you. With little oversight, it provides the ability to really work at your own pace. If you are motivated, or if you just love receiving compliments from wonderful people, the lack of oversight really doesn't hinder you at all. I found it very rewarding to work there, and hope that my upcoming jobs are filled with as many wonderful people as the Wesleyan University Library staff.
cons: There is an ability to slack off, depending on your position, and the temptation can be tough to avoid. Some days are more productive than others. There are also a few rude people who work there, which can occasionally add an unpleasant tinge to the day. However, those people are few and far between. Moreover, the tasks that some of the managers have to organize and deal with on a daily to weekly basis seem daunting and possibly overwhelming. As a student worker, I didn't personally experience this, but I witnessed some of the stress that it caused. Not sure if this was due to chronic under-staffing or a transitory period (trying to hire someone that would take on some of the load).

pros: Loved the faculty and students
cons: not the most up to date equipment

review_title: A great job to learn & make some money

pros: flexible hours, remote work, considerate bosses

pros:
- Good benefits package - sick leave, family medical leave, educational allowance for you and your family
- Great work-life balance
- Walkable, nice campus
- Depending on job, can be very interesting & full of purpose
- Great colleagues 
- Great students
- Interesting events on campus
cons:
- Lack of emphasis on professional development; sometimes they just don't care
- People camp out at their jobs for decades and people rarely get fired, new talent is made to fill in those gaps created by the overpaid higher-ups
- Almost punitive, ineffectual management style, demoralizing over time
- Tendency to "push things off" - reactive, not proactive style; old fashioned, reluctant to change
- Low pay compared to peer institutions, no transparency in pay structure, people who've been around forever are paid very high salaries 
- Nobody to go to if you have issues, HR is not trustworthy or flexible

basically, if you have good colleagues, you'll be fine, if you're fine with the pay

job_title: Campus Tour Guide in Middletown, CT
pros: I received a lot of institutional support for this role. The training program was extensive, thorough, and useful. The community of other guides was a huge factor in my enjoyment of the job.
cons: Having to answer more questions of parents than prospective students was never fun. Also, the office seems to be split into folks that see admissions as a central part of the yearly operations of the school and folks that see it as an instrument to achieve some temporary prestige (read: ranking) bump for the school. Working with non-student employees of the latter camp made this job conflicting to hold, as that kind of thinking represents everything I don't like about higher ed.

pros: Wesleyan justifiably maintains its reputation as a top-tier institution through its excellent faculty  and competitive student body. It offers a unique and wonderful experience for its students.
cons: Wesleyan has shown a disappointing lack of commitment to its non-academic staff in recent years. Salaries are woefully and egregiously uncompetitive, and the university seems not to care at all about lack of staff retention and the commensurate loss of talent, time, reputation, and institutional knowledge. Internal salary equity is a sad joke. Wesleyan will allocate resources toward flashy new buzzwordy programs without hesitation while leaving essential areas perpetually understaffed and campus infrastructure crumbling.

review_title: Wesleyan is a good place to work...for a few years.
pros: Open, liberal campus accepting of all different types of people. University is very progressive in all fronts, though sometimes it's a liability, as people become mired in identity politics. As far as I know, the pay scale was decent compared to other places, though affirmative action definitely let in quite a few underqualified employees
cons: Limiting location. Middletown is completely boring, and most of the administrative staff are local, and not very cosmopolitan. Many professors take off for the weekend. Student body can be obnoxious and overcoddled at times, but in general are really smart, motivated, interesting, and actually world-changing.

review_title: Wesleyan is a Place That Treats Faculty like Family
pros: Wesleyan treats employees very well because they are people with a positive outlook on life and success. Goals are high but that means achievements are definitely celebrated! Due to the quality of the Film School, you get the chance to see and work on events with high profile celebrities, which always keeps things interesting. Furthermore, if you are having personal issues, they are sensitive to your needs. The Staff genuinely cares about your well-being. It's easy to see why this University has such a high reputation.
cons: The interesting thing about working at Wesleyan is the facilities, some of which are acquired from neighboring properties. Occasionally, updates to these facilities are quite necessary. However, this depends highly on your department.

pros: Vibrant community; interesting people; interesting problems to solve; plenty of opportunities to learn; beautiful campus; excellent facilities, vacation, and benefits; collaborative environment where personal initiative and innovation are welcomed; values-based mission.
cons: As with any large, complex institution, there can be ardent personalities and colliding agendas. And sometimes good ideas stall and get buried because of too much to do and not enough executive support. In some cases, there is an unbalanced distribution of work, where staff with similar jobs have markedly disproportionate workloads.

review_title: Great school, amazing students, typical bureaucracy
pros:
The students here are overwhelmingly bright, engaged, inquisitive, and a joy to teach. 
Teaching colleagues are mostly collaborative, supportive, etc.
Departmental administration is mostly on your side.
cons:
* The higher-level administration is often disconnected from the student body and teaching staff. There is a cultural mismatch between the academic and administrative wings of the school that results in unnecessary strife and politics. These relationships can be borderline abusive.
* There is the typical academic bullying of younger teachers.
* You may encounter some tremendously entitled students .

review_title: Wonderful place to work, beautiful campus and atmosphere of learning.
pros: Working for an esteemed university is a great way to keep the mind sharp and to learn as much as you are contributing to your position. I learned so much from my co-workers in this very open-minded, sharing atmosphere. Not at all competitive.
cons: There's a challenging mental hurdle to overcome, which is that the university costs a fortune for students to attend, yet salaries will never be at the level they are in the corporate world.

pros: I worked with very lovely people in an engaging, creative, academic environment. The CFA has beautiful, brutalist architecture, great aesthetically pleasing place to work.
cons: I worked part time as part of my student work-studies program. I worked the maximum amount of hours possible and was only able to earn about $200 a week. Hardly enough to live.

pros: Working at the student helpdesk has been an incredibly rewarding experience for me. The whole student team is fantastic and the full time staff has been nothing but pleasant.
cons: There are very few opportunities for moving up this career path. Additionally, I find myself frequently bored at the desk.

pros: Relaxed environment, work hard play hard type mentality. Since it is a college campus, it is easy to interact with everyone both students and faculty.
cons: The same pro can be a con, some students are frustrating to work with and disrespectful. Work can get hard when serious problems occur.

pros: Lots of responsibility, many opportunities for extra work and for more access to higher ups within the Wesleyan fund.
cons: Sometimes overanalyzing work. though in the end this can be helpful for employees as it is a great feedback loop and is a valuable coaching opportunity

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Newton, MA
pros: There are plenty of smart people around:  good colleagues, good students.  I get full benefits.  Support staff is excellent, especially pedagogy center, academic computing.
cons: Not being a permanent part of the department, I feel a bit lost and anchorless.  The students are very good, but not as exceptional as everyone around Wes seems to think they are.

review_title: Good place to be a visiting professor

cons: None, really. Just the general problem of hiring VAPs instead of authorizing new tenure lines.

review_title: Wesleyan is a nice place to earn a graduate degree.
pros: Wesleyan has small class sizes with lots of one on one interaction with PIs.  It is a friendly, non-competitive environment.
cons: Wesleyan has no real graduate level classes because it is a smaller university.  The program also has no set rules, just guidelines, and these tent too change from person to person.
